question: If the Moon cannot be seen in a clear night sky on February 21 and the lunar phase repeats every 28 days, on what date will it next not be visible?

content.source_1: At new moon, the Moon lies near the Sun in the sky and its sunlit side faces away from Earth, so in a clear night sky it is essentially not visible.
content.source_2: In many introductory/classroom models, the lunar phase cycle is rounded to four weeks (28 days), so new moons are predicted to recur every 28 days.
content.source_3: Astronomically, the interval between new moons (the synodic month) averages about 29.53 days; in practice, successive new moons occur about 29.5 days apart.
content.source_4: Calendar arithmetic from February 21: adding 28 days lands on March 21 in a common (non‑leap) year and March 20 in a leap year; adding about 29.5 days lands around March 23 (± roughly half a day) regardless of leap status.
content.source_5: In the Gregorian calendar, February has 28 days in common years and 29 days in leap years.
